name: 1,2,4-tribromo-5,6-dimethoxy-3-methylbenzene
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-2478

name: 1,2,4-tribromo-5,6-dimethoxy-3-methylbenzene
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-2478
Reason: To predict the melting point of 1,2,4-tribromo-5,6-dimethoxy-3-methylbenzene, we will start with the basic unit of benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5 degrees Celsius. Each substituent on the benzene ring can have an effect on the overall melting point based on its own properties. The bromine atoms, being large and heavy atoms, significantly increase the molecular weight and the rigidity of the molecule due to strong intermolecular van der Waals' forces, which we expect to raise the melting point by about +20 per bromine atom. The methoxy groups are electron-donating and can engage in dipole-dipole interactions, increasing the melting point; we estimate this increase to be about +10 per methoxy group. The methyl group is small and electron-donating, contributing slightly to the molecular weight and possibly packing efficiency; we estimate an increase of +5 for the methyl group. Summing these adjustments gives us a prediction for the melting point.
Prediction: 5.5 (base benzene) + 3(20) (bromine atoms) + 2(10) (methoxy groups) + 5 (methyl group) = 5.5 + 60 + 20 + 5 = 90.5 degrees Celsius
